abstract.p: Letter by Dennis Johnson of Children's Health Fund on report that up to half of children in New York's Child Health Plus should be enrolled in Medicaid instead; warns that switching children between programs threatens health care access

block.p: A Sept. 30 front-page article reports that up to half of the 538,000 children in Child Health Plus in New York State may be inappropriately enrolled in the program when in fact they are eligible for Medicaid.
Switching children between programs threatens their health care access. There must be a transition that preserves continuity of care.

A Sept. 30 front-page article reports that up to half of the 538,000 children in Child Health Plus in New York State may be inappropriately enrolled in the program when in fact they are eligible for Medicaid.
Switching children between programs threatens their health care access. There must be a transition that preserves continuity of care.
In cases where the managed care provider serves both the Child Health Plus and Medicaid populations, this internal transition should be easy.
In the case of managed care plans that serve only Child Health Plus, they should assist efforts to enroll eligible children in Medicaid.
We should ask why we continue to take a fragmented approach to a problem that would best be solved by guaranteeing access to insurance coverage through a single program for all children who need it.
DENNIS JOHNSON Vice President for External Affairs Children's Health Fund New York, Oct. 2, 2000
